Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Therapeutic Alternatives in the Criminal Courts

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This study examines the growing use of therapy as an alternative to criminal prosecution in the United States. Tens of thousands of defendants each year are now offered a pathway to avoid felony convictions by completing therapeutic activities and passing drug tests for designated periods of time. By analyzing the role and consequences of these pretrial diversion programs, this project will contribute to knowledge about the impacts of the contemporary criminal justice system. It also will provide information to policymakers, legal practitioners, and the public as they determine the role that pretrial diversion should play in criminal justice reform efforts and in the provision of mental healthcare.

Despite the growing popularity of pretrial diversion programs across the U.S., little sociological research has yet examined their impacts. This research draws on national and local datasets, document analysis, an original survey experiment, participant observation, and interviews with attorneys, defendants, and therapists to illuminate the consequences of diversion nationally and to explore variation between programs. Three questions are addressed: 1) how effective diversion is as a tool to promote decarceration; 2) what the implications of diversion are for social inequality; and 3) what effects diversion has on the lives of defendants. Findings will contribute to scholarship on contemporary U.S. criminal justice system reform and on the consequences of using the court system to provide mental health treatment. In addition, this research will provide empirical information to jurisdictions seeking to expand diversionary options or to design new programs, to policymakers in search of effective criminal justice alternatives, and to groups involved in advocating for penal reform.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The U.S. criminal legal system has reached an unprecedented scale. As elected officials face growing pressure to reduce its reach, few reforms have garnered more widespread support than programs that offer individuals treatment in place of punishment. In particular, pretrial diversion programs run by prosecutors have become a gold standard for many advocates, since they allow defendants to exit the court system without criminal records. But even as such programs expand across the country, encouraged by substantial philanthropic and federal funding, few studies have examined their consequences on the ground.

This award helped to support twelve months of ethnographic fieldwork, including participant observation in a diversion program and 108 in-depth interviews with legal decision makers and diversion participants, along with the collection of administrative and experimental data. Drawing on that diverse set of data, I asked three main questions about the ways diversion shapes the operations of the criminal courts.

First, I asked whether the introduction of diversion changes prosecutors’ decision making. I found that prosecutors are more likely to charge cases when they are given a pretrial diversion option, increasing the number of people brought into the court system. They also tend to pursue harsher sentences for defendants who enter diversion but are not able to complete the program—about half of those who enter—than for their non-diverted counterparts. These findings raise concerns that availability of diversion can make legal outcomes worse for some defendants.

Second, I examined the relational dynamics that emerged in the mandatory treatment environment, in which therapists are required to report to the courts on their clients’ behavior and their clients face severe punishment if those reports are negative. I found that treatment participants negotiated their fear of criminal punishment by attempting to argue their legal cases in therapy; hiding information from therapists in order to appear “low risk”; and resigning themselves to mutely serving out time in treatment sessions. The result was a treatment environment that was structured by the logics of the criminal courts.

Third, I examined the criteria used to decide which defendants are returned to court prior to completion of diversion. Although courtroom decision makers view diversion (non)completion as a clear signal of defendants’ willingness to accept help and to change, in fact participants’ ability to finish diversion is fundamentally shaped by their health, financial resources, and self-advocacy. The result is that individuals who are poor, Black, and ill are disproportionately returned to court and often punished more harshly as a result of their participation in diversion.

In addition to shedding light on a popular criminal legal reform that has received little scrutiny, this study points to an important shift in the ways criminal courts operate. As treatment-based alternatives expand to receive many hundreds of thousands of defendants every year, legal outcomes are increasingly determined less by the charges or evidence against those defendants than by their ability successfully to perform compliance in sites hidden from public view. As our findings illustrate, individuals’ performance of compliance is fundamentally structured by social inequality. Ultimately, this form of adjudication can both obscure and intensify the systematic and disproportionate punishment of people who are poor, Black, and sick.

I have completed a dissertation and am currently at work on three journal articles and a book project based on these data.
